_prev_prog_3.Description: Milk Specialties has prepared a unifie d Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements). At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68, and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials), and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal R egulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Milk Specialties Global has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM 

related activities. 



1.1 Milk Specialties Global, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Milk Specialties Global has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                     | Process Chemical                    | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration Process      Anhydrous Ammonia                     11,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program bas

ed on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Milk Specialties operates a production facility for dairy products in Visalia, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(15) Silo's

(2) Ice Builders

(4) Falling Film Chillers

(2) Plate and Frame Heat Exchangers 

(1) Vat Room Evaporative Cooler



The heat exchangers are equipped with surge drums as required for flooded operation. 



Most control valve groups are located at a working level, on a working platform, or on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained inside a machinery room, outside machinery area, or on the roof directly above the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:



Machinery Room

(6) Reciprocating compressors

(6) Oil separators

(1) Ice Builder with an integral Surge Drum

(1) Falling Film Chiller with an integral Surge Drum

(2) Oil Pot



Outside Machinery Area

(1) High Pressure Receiver

(2) Suction Accumulators

(2) Transfer Vessels

(1) Ice Builder with an integral Surge Drum

(3) Falling Film Chillers each with an integral Surge Drum

(3) Oil Pots

(1) Auto Purger



Machinery Room Roof

(1) Evaporative condenser

(3) Ventilation fans



Inside Silo Area

(6) Surge Drums

(6) Silos

(6) Oil Pots



Filtration Room

(1) Evaporator

(1) Surge Drum    



Chiller Room

(1) Surge Drum

(1) Plate and Frame

(1) Oil Pot (located outside room)



Butter Silo Area

(1) Surge Drum

(6) Silo's



Receiving Silo Area

(3) Surge Drums

(3) Silo's

(3) Oil Pots



The system operates as follo

ws: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each heat exchanger, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure surge drum mounted above the heat exchanger. From the surge drum, low pressure liquid is circulated through the heat exchanger. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the surge drum. The suction gas is returned from the surge drums through a suction return line to the main suction accumulators.  From the main suction accumulators, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 



There are two ammonia detectors installed inside the refrigeration machinery room. One sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate the mechanical ventilation system and activate an audible alarm and strobe. The second sensor is set at 200 ppm, which will shut down all refrigeration machinery inside the refrigeration machinery room and activate an audible alarm and strobe.



An emergency control box is installed on the north exterior wall of the refrigeration machinery room, which contains four valves. The high and both low sides of the system each have a valve that would discharge to atmosphere. The connecting pipe between the high and low sides have one equalizer valve that would equalize the system.

The ammonia refrigeration system at Milk Specialties consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.

As such, the refrigeration system at Milk Specialties is treated as a single process.



RAGAGEP Statement



Ammonia Refrigeration



The process equipment was inspected during the PHA for the purpose of verifying that the process was designed, fabricated, and is being operated in accordance with applicable industry standards. It is unclear which 

codes and standards were followed in the original design and construction of the refrigeration system. The pressure vessels are equipped with nameplates which span the years 1994-2002. Due to the fact that the system is not equipped with an ammonia diffusion tank, it is the judgment of the PHA team that the system most closely aligns with the 1991 Uniform Mechanical/Fire Codes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Milk Specialties Global has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Milk Specialties Global facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates year-round. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 11,000 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and tr

ansactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Milk Specialties Global's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Milk Specialties Global has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Milk Specialties Global continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all

necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Milk Specialties Global's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Milk Specialties Global's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Milk Specialties Global has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Milk Specialties Global has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Milk Specialties Global now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Milk Specialties Global employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Milk Specialties Global will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
